It’s been a very long time since I’ve done one of these. the sum of forces in the X dir=0, correct?

There is a maximum speed. If the car is to over the max speed, the car will leave the ground. If we treat the speed bump as an arc of a circle, we could say that the centripetal force is equal to mg - R (as they act in opposite directions). => (mv^2)/r = mg - R. If the car is to leave the ground, R will equal 0 since there is no contact. Using R=0, we can calculate the max speed by rearranging the expression to give v = root (gr), which is the maximum speed that a car can go over the speed bump without flying - it does not simply get attracted more to the speed bump with higher speed.
R is the reaction/normal force

This is a pretty late reply but I've been searching for the answer myself - I'm fairly sure that the normal force is down because the surface (track) is above the cart; a surface such as a track can only "push on a object" so the reaction of this must go downward. Hope this makes sense : )

Adam Chavez In these roller coaster problems, assuming there is no acceleration, yes, no net force would mean a constant speed, so you would be correct. If there was acceleration, there would be a net force forwards towards positive x values, so the sum in the x direction wold equal some positive number.
